history.content:
No. Companies don't go back on their word. Especially once you get and sign the official letter. 

If they do cancel, complain to the Career Center and the company could get blacklisted. 
-----
Just from a perspective of can they actually go back on their word, yes it is legally possible. Usually, employment contracts are "at will", meaning either party can end the agreement at any time. However, I agree with the anon above - companies don't usually go back on their word, especially once the offer is signed. It looks bad on their end and could lead to career centers and other third party employment services blacklisting them. Congrats on your offer!

No. Companies don't go back on their word. Especially once you get and sign the official letter. 

If they do cancel, complain to the Career Center and the company could get blacklisted.

children.subject: Verbal contracts are not binding so until you actually get it in writing they can take it back...it probably won't happen though!
op here, thanks everyone for the feedback! i am mostly worried just because i havent received my offer letter yet but it is still super early so just waiting it out

history.content:
I’m in a really odd situation where I just received a phone call saying that I got an offer from a pretty well known company and with amazing pay. I am honestly in shock and wondering if they even got the right person. I had literally little to no experience in the role they’re hiring for and although I did well in my second interview, in my first interview, the hiring manager looked so bored and frustrated. But still the same day of my interviews, I got a call saying they were giving me an offer?? 

Can the company go back on this?? I would be so sad if they were like nah never mind, sorry if I sound naive, this is my first time internship searching
history.subject: Can a company change their mind on their offer?
